metadata.title: Nonlocal strain gradient plate model for nonlinear large-amplitude vibrations of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates reinforced with GPLs

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Composite Structures
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/compstruct
Nonlocal strain gradient plate model for nonlinear large-amplitude vibrations of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates reinforced with GPLs
Saeid Sahmania,⁎, Mohammad Mohammadi Aghdama, Timon Rabczukb
a Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, 15875-4413 Tehran, Iran b Institute of Structural Mechanics, Bauhaus Universität-Weimar, Marienstr 15, D-99423 Weimar, Germany
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Porous materials Nanostructures Nonlinear dynamics Size dependency Nanocomposites
A B S T R A C T
Because of rapid development of manufacturing technology, functionally graded porous materials have gained commercially attraction in promoted engineering applications. It is common to reinforce the porous materials with nanofillers to improve their mechanical properties efficiently. The prime objective of the present investigation is to explore the size dependency in nonlinear large-amplitude vibrational response of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates reinforced with graphene platelets (GPLs). To accomplish this purpose, the newly proposed unconventional continuum theory namely as the nonlocal strain gradient theory incorporating size effects more comprehensively is adopted to the refined exponential shear deformation plate theory. Based upon the closed-cell Gaussian-Random field scheme in conjunction with the Halpin-Tsai micromechanical modelling, the mechanical properties of the porous material with uniform and three different functionally graded patterns of porosity dispersion reinforced with GPLs are extracted. Using Hamilton's principle, the nonclassical form of differential equations of motion are derived. Thereafter, an improved perturbation technique is put to use to construct analytical expression for the nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear frequency associated with the large-amplitude vibration of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates reinforced with GPLs. It is indicated that by increasing the plate deflection, the significance of the both size effects on the nonlinear frequency of the porous micro/nano-plates decreases. Also, it is displayed that for vibrations with higher amplitude, the role of porosity dispersion pattern in the significance of size effects on the nonlinear frequency of functionally graded micro/nano-plates becomes more important.
1. Introduction
Rapid advances in characterization methods and design of sophisticated material have made the capability to produce porous materials with attractive mechanical properties and biomimetic applications. In order to improve the mechanical characteristics of porous materials, it is efficient to reinforce them with nanofillers with outstanding high strength and light weight. In recent years, several investigations have been carried out to study the wide range of porous material applications. Gain et al. [1] explored that microstructural and mechanical properties of manufactured porous hydroxyapatite-zirconia nanocomposite material. Pang et al. [2] synthesized carbon nanotube-reinforced porous iron oxide containing porous Cu substrate to enlarge surface area as a superior anode material using for lithium ion battery. Gong et al. [3] examined the degradation performance of lotus nanofiber-alginate porous biomaterials for using in medical fields. Li et al.
[4] utilized the foam-gelcasting method to fabricate mullite whisker reinforced porous anorthite ceramics having high strength as well as low thermal conductivity. Ghorbanpour Arani et al. [5] presented a study deals with the dynamic analysis of rectangular porous plates resting on an elastic foundation based on the linear poroelasticity theory. They also investigated the free vibration response of rectangular plates made of porous Y-foam, G-foam, and Coustone materials [6]. Wu et al. [7] developed foam-gelcasting-freeze drying method to produce fiber reinforced highly porous ceramics having considerable mechanical strength.
Several unconventional continuum theories of elasticity have been proposed and employed to take different size dependencies into consideration [8–44]. Based upon reviewing the historical background, it can be concluded that the size effect coming from the stress nonlocality leads to softening-stiffness influence, but the strain gradient small scale effect results in a hardening-stiffness effect. It means that no one of

these non-lassical continuum theories could perfectly cover the small scale features at nanoscale. Thereby, Lim et al. [45] developed a new size-dependent elasticity theory namely as nonlocal strain gradient theory which includes simultaneously the both softening and stiffening influences to describe the small scale effects more efficiently.
After that, some investigations have been carried out using the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory to describe the size-dependent mechanical behaviors. For instance, Li and Hu [46] reported the small sale effects on the nonlinear bending and free vibration behavior of functionally graded nanobeams on the basis of the nonlocal strain gradient theory. Simsek [47] used nonlocal strain gradient theory to capture the size effects on the nonlinear natural frequencies of functionally graded Euler-Bernoulli nanobeams. Tang et al. [48] analyzed the viscoelastic wave propagation in carbon nanotubes based upon the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. Li et al. [49] developed a nonlocal strain gradient Timoshenko beam model for free vibration analysis of two-constituent functionally graded nanobeams. Lu et al. [50] proposed higher-order nonlocal strain gradient beam models within the frameworks of Euler-Bernoulli and Timoshenko beam theories for bending and buckling analysis of nanobeams. Shahsavari et al. [51] used the theory of nonlocal strain gradient elasticity to examine the size dependency in shear buckling of nanoplates in hygrothermal environment. Sahmani and Aghdam [52,53] predicted the linear and nonlinear vibrational responses of lipid supramolecular micro/nanotubules with the prebuckling and postbuckling domains including nonlocality and strain gradient size effects. Li and Hu [54] implemented the nonlocal stress and microstructure-dependent strain gradient size effects on the postbuckling behavior of functionally graded nanobeams. Zhu and Li [55] proposed a closed form solution for a small-scaled rod in tension modeled by the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. They also studied the size-dependent longitudinal dynamic response of nanorods via an integral form of the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity [56]. Li et al. [57] utilized the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory within the framework of the Euler-Bernoulli beam theory to explore bending, buckling and free vibration of axially functionally graded nanobeams. Zeighampour et al. [58] explored the wave propagation in double-walled carbon nanotubes conveying fluid based upon the nonlocal strain gradient shell model. Sahmani et al. [59] anticipated the nonlinear bending behavior of porous micro/nano-beams reinforced with graphene platelets based on the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity. Zeighampour et al. [60] employed the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity to investigate the wave propagation in viscoelastic single-walled carbon nanotubes. Imani and Biglari [61] introduced a nonlocal strain gradient Timoshenko beam model to capture size effects on the buckling and vibration responses of microtubules in axons. Li et al. [62] added the effect of size dependency in thickness direction to the nonlocal strain gradient beam model to analyze the size-dependent buckling behavior of nanobeams more accurately.
In this work, the size-dependent nonlinear large-amplitude vibrational behavior of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates reinforced with graphene platelets (GPLs) is predicted incorporating the both hardening- and softening-stiffness small scale effects. To this purpose, the strain gradient theory of elasticity is applied to the refined exponential shear deformation plate theory. The mechanical properties of the porous material are captured relevant to a uniform and three different functionally graded patterns of porosity dispersion filled with GPLs. Thereafter, an improved perturbation solving process together with the Galerkin method is put to use to extract analytical expression for the size-dependent nonlinear frequency-deflection response of the porous micro/nano-plates.

3. Nonlocal strain gradient exponential shear deformable plate model
As a refined shear deformation plate theory, in the exponential shear deformable plate theory, there is no need to utilize a shear correction factor, and with the same number of independent variables, the bending components do not contribute toward the shear components and vice versa. Therefore, on the basis of the exponential shear deformation plate theory, the displacement field can be written as

5. Numerical results and discussion
Herein, selected numerical results are presented to study the size dependency in the nonlinear large –amplitude vibration response of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates with various patterns of porosity dispersion reinforced with GPLs. The matrix material is assumed to be made of titanium with = =E GPa ν116 , 0.33m m , and =ρ Kg m4506 /m 3 [77]. Additionally, for the reinforcement phase of GPL, it is assumed that = =E TPa ν1.01 ,GPL GPL = =ρ Kg m h nm0.186, 1062.5 / , 0.3GPL GPL3 , =L nm5GPL , and =b nm2.5GPL . The values of geometric parameters for the functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates are considered as =h nm10 and = =L L nm2001 2 . Firstly, the validity and accuracy of the present solving process are checked. For this purpose, by ignoring the terms related to the nonlocality and strain gradient size dependency, the frequency ratio (ω ω/NL L) of a square isotropic plate is calculated corresponding to different vibration amplitudes and compared with those reported by Han and Petyt [78] using the hierarchical finite element method. It an be seen from Table 1 that there is an excellent between the results of two methods which confirms the validity as well as the accuracy of the current solution methodology.
In Fig. 2, the variation of frequency ratio (ω ω/NL L) with the maximum deflection of the functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates with uniform dispersion pattern (pattern A) reinforced with GPLs is depicted corresponding to different small scale parameters. It is revealed that at a specific value of deflection, the nonlocal size effect causes to increase the frequency ratio, but the strain gradient size dependency leads to reduce it. In other words, by taking the nonlocality
and strain gradient small scale effect, the difference between the nonlinear and linear frequencies of porous micro/nano-plates increases and decreases, respectively. This anticipation is more significant at higher value of the plate deflection.
In order to indicate the influence of size effects on the natural frequency of porous micro/nano-plates more clearly, the values of ωL corresponding to various patterns of porosity dispersion and different values of small scale parameters and porosity coefficient are given in Table 2. It is found that the type of porosity dispersion pattern and the value of porosity coefficient have a negligible influence on the significance of size dependency in the value of ωL. However, at a specific porosity coefficient and pattern of porosity dispersion, the increment in the value of ωL due to the strain gradient size effect is more considerable than the reduction in the value of ωL due to the nonlocality.
Fig. 3 illustrates the influence of the porosity dispersion pattern on the variation of the frequency ratio with maximum deflection of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates reinforced with GPLs corresponding to different porosity coefficients. It can be seen that by increasing the value of porosity coefficient, the role of porosity dispersion pattern in the nonlinear large-amplitude vibration response of the porous micro/nano-plates becomes more important. Also, it is found that at a specific value of maximum deflection, the frequency ratio (the difference between linear and nonlinear frequencies) of the functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates with patterns C and D is minimum and maximum, respectively.
The influence of porosity coefficient on the size-dependent variation of frequency ratio with maximum deflection of functionally graded
porous micro/nano-plates reinforced with GPLs is shown in Fig. 4 corresponding to different patterns of porosity dispersion. It is observed that through increment the value of porosity coefficient, the frequency ratio associated with a specific maximum deflection increases,
especially for higher value of the maximum deflection. Moreover, it is seen that among various types of porosity dispersion pattern, the influence of porosity coefficient on the nonlinear vibrations of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates with patterns D and C is maximum and minimum, respectively.
In Tables 3 and 4, the size-dependent dimensionless nonlinear frequencies of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates with various patterns of porosity dispersion and values of porosity coefficient are tabulated corresponding to different nonlocal and strain gradient parameters, respectively. It is indicated that for all values of porosity coefficient, maximum deflection, and different types of porosity dispersion pattern, the significance of the strain gradient size dependency on the nonlinear frequency of functionally graded porous micro/nano-
shells is more that of the nonlocal one. Furthermore, it can be seen that by increasing the plate deflection, the significance of the both size effects on the nonlinear frequency of the porous micro/nano-plates decreases. Additionally, it is observed that for nonlinear vibrations with higher amplitude, the role of porosity dispersion pattern in the significance of the both types of size dependency becomes more important.
Fig. 5 demonstrates the influence of volume fraction of GPL reinforcements on the nonlinear large-amplitude vibrational response of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates with uniform porosity dispersion (Pattern A) corresponding to different values of small scale parameters. It is found that by increasing the volume fraction of the nanofillers, the frequency ratio associated with a specific value of the plate deflection reduces. This prediction is more significant for higher vibration amplitude and lower value of VGPL. In addition, it is revealed that by taking the nonlocality into consideration, the influence of GPL volume fraction enhances, so it leads to increase the gap between different curves. However, the strain gradient size dependency has an opposite effect and decreases the influence of VGPL.
6. Concluding remarks
The main aim of the current study was to investigate the nonlinear large-amplitude vibrations of functionally graded porous micro/nanoplates reinforced with GPLs in the presence of nonlocality and strain gradient size dependency. To this purpose, the unconventional continuum theory of nonlocal strain gradient elasticity was implemented into the refined exponential shear deformation plate theory. With the aid of the closed-cell Gaussian-Random field scheme in conjunction with the Halpin-Tsai micromechanical modelling, the mechanical properties of the porous material with uniform and three different functionally graded patterns of porosity dispersion reinforced with GPLs were achieved. Finally, an improved perturbation technique together with the Galerkin method was employed to express the sizedependent nonlinear frequency-deflection response of the functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates.
It was found that at a specific value of deflection, the nonlocal size effect causes to increase the frequency ratio, but the strain gradient size dependency leads to reduce it. Also, It was observed that for all values of porosity coefficient, maximum deflection, and different types of porosity dispersion pattern, the significance of the strain gradient size dependency on the nonlinear frequency of functionally graded porous micro/nano-shells is more that of the nonlocal one. It was revealed that at a specific porosity coefficient and pattern of porosity dispersion, the increment in the value of natural frequency due to the strain gradient size effect is more considerable than the reduction in the value of it due to the nonlocality. Moreover, it was seen that at a specific value of maximum deflection, the difference between linear and nonlinear frequencies of the functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates with patterns C and D is minimum and maximum, respectively.
Furthermore, it was demonstrated that by increasing the plate deflection, the significance of the both size effects on the nonlinear frequency of the porous micro/nano-plates decreases. It was indicated that by taking the nonlocality into consideration, the influence of GPL volume fraction enhances, so it leads to increase the gap between different curves. However, the strain gradient size dependency has an opposite effect and decreases the influence of VGPL.

metadata.abstractText: Because of rapid development of manufacturing technology, functionally graded porous materials have gained commercially attraction in promoted engineering applications. It is common to reinforce the porous materials with nanofillers to improve their mechanical properties efficiently. The prime objective of the present investigation is to explore the size dependency in nonlinear large-amplitude vibrational response of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates reinforced with graphene platelets (GPLs). To accomplish this purpose, the newly proposed unconventional continuum theory namely as the nonlocal strain gradient theory incorporating size effects more comprehensively is adopted to the refined exponential shear deformation plate theory. Based upon the closed-cell Gaussian-Random field scheme in conjunction with the Halpin-Tsai micromechanical modelling, the mechanical properties of the porous material with uniform and three different functionally graded patterns of porosity dispersion reinforced with GPLs are extracted. Using Hamilton's principle, the nonclassical form of differential equations of motion are derived. Thereafter, an improved perturbation technique is put to use to construct analytical expression for the nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear frequency associated with the large-amplitude vibration of functionally graded porous micro/nano-plates reinforced with GPLs. It is indicated that by increasing the plate deflection, the significance of the both size effects on the nonlinear frequency of the porous micro/nano-plates decreases. Also, it is displayed that for vibrations with higher amplitude, the role of porosity dispersion pattern in the significance of size effects on the nonlinear frequency of functionally graded micro/nano-plates becomes more important.
